explanation:
OS_CHECK_APINAME (macro) - This validates the passed sem_name; its implementation may use string-comparison logic (or call helpers) so it must be inspected to ensure it does not use memcmp on NUL-terminated strings.

OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew - The target passes sem_name into this routine. AllocateNew is responsible for finding/allocating an object slot by name and therefore is a primary place where name comparisons may occur (it can call lower-level match routines that might use memcmp).

OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch - This is the likely lower-level search routine used by ObjectIdAllocateNew to find an existing name match. It is the most relevant symbol for detecting any memcmp use to compare NUL-terminated strings.

OS_OBJECT_INIT (macro) - The function uses this macro to save the name into the new table entry. Its implementation may copy or initialize the name buffer and could contain mem* or string routines; inspect it to ensure no memcmp is being misused for string comparison.

OS_MutSemCreate_Impl - The platform-specific create implementation is called while the record is set up; it may perform additional name checks or bookkeeping and could contain comparisons of stored names, so it must be examined.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken - Called (directly or indirectly) by the implementation routines to map tokens to table indices; some implementations perform name or memory comparisons here, so include it in the review.

OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew - Finalizes the allocation and may perform final checks or notifications that reference the object name; inspect to confirm it does not use memcmp for NUL-terminated string comparisons.

Note: The above symbols are the ones that directly handle sem_name or are the immediate search/initialization/finalization routines reachable from the target function. Reviewing their implementations (and any macros they expand to) is sufficient to determine whether memcmp is being used to compare null-terminated strings in the create path.
